xml:
AZITHROMYCIN

List of individual interactants: Azithromycin

96034006 Macrolides and related drugs MACROLIDES Indications and dose

Prevention of secondary case of invasive group A streptococcal infection in patients who are allergic to penicillin

By mouth

  • Child 6 months–11 years

    12 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 500 mg) for 5 days.

  • Child 12–17 years

    500 mg once daily for 5 days.

  • Adult

    500 mg once daily for 5 days.

Respiratory-tract infections, otitis media, skin and soft-tissue infections

By mouth

  • Child 6 months–17 years

    10 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 500 mg) for 3 days.

  • Child 6 months–17 years (body-weight 15–25 kg)

    200 mg once daily for 3 days.

  • Child 6 months–17 years (body-weight 26–35 kg)

    300 mg once daily for 3 days.

  • Child 6 months–17 years (body-weight 36–45 kg)

    400 mg once daily for 3 days.

  • Child 6 months–17 years (body-weight 46 kg and above)

    500 mg once daily for 3 days.

  • Adult

    500 mg once daily for 3 days, alternatively initially 500 mg once daily for 1 day, then 250 mg once daily for 4 days.

Uncomplicated genital chlamydial infections

Non-gonococcal urethritis

By mouth

  • Child 12–17 years

    1 g for 1 dose.

  • Adult

    1 g for 1 dose.

Uncomplicated gonorrhoea

By mouth

  • Adult

    1 g for 1 dose.

Lyme disease

By mouth

  • Adult

    500 mg daily for 7–10 days.

Mild to moderate typhoid due to multiple-antibacterial resistant organisms

By mouth

  • Adult

    500 mg daily for 7 days.

Community-acquired pneumonia, low to moderate severity

By mouth

  • Adult

    500 mg once daily for 3 days, alternatively initially 500 mg once daily for 1 day, then 250 mg once daily for 4 days.

Community-acquired pneumonia, high severity

Initially by intravenous infusion

  • Adult

    Initially 500 mg once daily for at least 2 days, then (by mouth) 500 mg once daily for a total duration of 7–10 days.

Antibacterial prophylaxis for insertion of intra-uterine device

By mouth

  • Adult

    1 g for 1 dose.

Trachomatous conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis

Purulent bacterial conjunctivitis

To the eye

  • Child

    Apply twice daily for 3 days, review if no improvement after 3 days of treatment.

  • Adult

    Apply twice daily for 3 days, review if no improvement after 3 days of treatment.

 Unlicensed use

With oral use in children

Not licensed for typhoid fever, Lyme disease, chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in cystic fibrosis, or prophylaxis of group A streptococcal infection.

With oral use in adults

Oral azithromycin not licensed for trachoma which results from chronic infection with Chlamydia trachomatis .

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Not licensed for uncomplicated gonorrhoea, mild or moderate typhoid due to multiple-antibacterial-resistant organisms, Lyme disease, or prophylaxis of group A streptococcal infection.

Not licensed for community-acquired pneumonia (high severity) when oral treatment continues for more than 3 days.
Interactions

Appendix 1 (macrolides).

Caution with concomitant use of drugs that prolong the QT interval.
Side-effects

Common or very common

When used by eye

blurred vision; ocular burning; ocular discomfort; ocular pruritus

With intravenous use

anorexia (in adults); arthralgia (in adults); disturbances in taste (in adults); disturbances in vision (in adults); dizziness (in adults); dyspepsia (in adults); flatulence (in adults); headache (in adults); malaise (in adults); paraesthesia (in adults); reversible hearing loss (sometimes with tinnitus) after long-term therapy (in adults)

With oral use

anorexia (in adults); anorexia (in children); arthralgia (in adults); arthralgia (in children); disturbances in taste (in adults); disturbances in taste (in children); disturbances in vision (in adults); disturbances in vision (in children); dizziness (in adults); dizziness (in children); dyspepsia (in adults); dyspepsia (in children); flatulence (in adults); flatulence (in children); headache (in adults); headache (in children); malaise (in adults); malaise (in children); paraesthesia (in adults); paraesthesia (in children); reversible hearing loss (sometimes with tinnitus) after long-term therapy (in adults); reversible hearing loss (sometimes with tinnitus) after long-term therapy (in children)

Uncommon

When used by eye

conjunctival hyperaemia; eyelid eczema; eyelid erythema; eyelid oedema; keratitis

With intravenous use

anxiety (in adults); chest pain (in adults); constipation (in adults); gastritis (in adults); hypoaesthesia (in adults); leucopenia (in adults); oedema (in adults); photosensitivity (in adults); sleep disturbances (in adults)

With oral use

anxiety (in adults); anxiety (in children); chest pain (in adults); chest pain (in children); constipation (in adults); constipation (in children); gastritis (in adults); gastritis (in children); hypoaesthesia (in adults); hypoaesthesia (in children); leucopenia (in adults); leucopenia (in children); oedema (in adults); oedema (in children); photosensitivity (in adults); photosensitivity (in children); sleep disturbances (in adults); sleep disturbances (in children)

Rare

With intravenous use

agitation (in adults)

With oral use

agitation (in adults); agitation (in children)

Frequency not known

With intravenous use

acute renal failure (in adults); convulsions (in adults); haemolytic anaemia (in adults); interstitial nephritis (in adults); smell disturbances (in adults); syncope (in adults); thrombocytopenia (in adults); tongue discoloration (in adults)

With oral use

acute renal failure (in adults); acute renal failure (in children); convulsions (in adults); convulsions (in children); haemolytic anaemia (in adults); haemolytic anaemia (in children); interstitial nephritis (in adults); interstitial nephritis (in children); smell disturbances (in adults); smell disturbances (in children); syncope (in adults); syncope (in children); thrombocytopenia (in adults); thrombocytopenia (in children); tongue discoloration (in adults); tongue discoloration (in children)
Pregnancy

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Manufacturers advise use only if adequate alternatives not available.

With oral use in children

Manufacturers advise use only if adequate alternatives not available.
Breast feeding

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Present in milk; use only if no suitable alternatives.

With oral use in children

Present in milk; use only if no suitable alternatives.
Hepatic impairment

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Manufacturers advise avoid in severe liver disease–no information available.

With oral use in children

Manufacturers advise avoid in severe liver disease–no information available.
Renal impairment

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Use with caution if eGFR less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

With oral use in children

Use with caution if estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2.
Directions for administration

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (Zedbac ), give intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

Reconstitute 500 mg with 4.8 mL water for injections to produce a 100 mg/mL solution, then dilute 5 mL of solution with infusion fluid to a final concentration of 1 or 2 mg/mL; give the 1 mg/mL solution over 3 hours or give the 2 mg/mL solution over 1 hour.
Prescribing and dispensing information

Flavours of oral liquid formulations may include cherry or banana.
Patient and carer advice

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Azithromycin for bacterial infections

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/azithromycin-bacterial-infections-0

Profession specific information
Dental practitioners' formulary

With oral use

Azithromycin Capsules may be prescribed.

With oral use

Azithromycin Tablets may be prescribed.

With oral use

Azithromycin Oral Suspension 200 mg/5 mL may be prescribed.
Exceptions to legal category

With oral use

Azithromycin tablets can be sold to the public for the treatment of confirmed, asymptomatic Chlamydia trachomatis genital infection in those over 16 years of age, and for the epidemiological treatment of their sexual partners, subject to maximum single dose of 1 g, maximum daily dose 1 g, and a pack size of 1 g.
Medicinal forms

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension

 Drugs Tablet Capsule Oral suspension Powder for solution for infusion Eye drops Drug classifications Prescribing in dental practice Antiprotozoal drugs Gastro-intestinal system infections, bacterial Antibacterials, use for prophylaxis Tuberculosis Skin infections, bacterial Ear infections, bacterial Nose infections, bacterial Macrolides Oropharynx infections, bacterial Contraceptives, hormonal Genital system infections, bacterial Eye, infections of Respiratory system infections, bacterial Azithromycin MACROLIDES Drugs Tablet Capsule Oral suspension Powder for solution for infusion Eye drops
